title: The Beloved's Invitation
shortSummary: Song of Solomon Chapter 2 poetically depicts the intimate love between the bride and her beloved, using vivid natural imagery to express affection, longing, and mutual delight. The chapter highlights the beauty of love under God's design and the tender call to embrace joy and commitment in the relationship.
timeline: c. 10th century BC - Period of Solomon's reign and traditional dating of the Song of Solomon

keyCharacters.name: The Shulamite Woman
keyCharacters.description: The bride who expresses her love and admiration for her beloved, using rich imagery to describe their relationship.

keyCharacters.name: The Beloved
keyCharacters.description: The bridegroom who calls his love to arise and come away, symbolizing the mutual affection and invitation to intimacy.

keyCharacters.name: Daughters of Jerusalem
keyCharacters.description: The chorus or onlookers who are addressed by the bride, serving as witnesses and advisors in the love relationship.

definitions.definition: A fragrant flower of the plain of Sharon, symbolizing beauty and purity in the bride’s self-description.
A delicate and beautiful flower growing in low places, representing humility and loveliness.
Large bottles or containers for wine, symbolizing refreshment and joy in the context of love.
Small animals known for damaging vineyards, used metaphorically for small problems or sins that can spoil a relationship.

outline.heading: The Bride’s Self-Description and Love for Her Beloved
outline.description: The bride uses floral and orchard imagery to describe herself and her beloved, emphasizing beauty, delight, and the sweetness of their love under his protective shadow.

outline.heading: The Beloved’s Invitation and the Banner of Love
outline.description: The bride recounts being brought to a place of celebration under the banner of love, highlighting the security and comfort found in their relationship.

outline.heading: A Charge to the Daughters of Jerusalem
outline.description: The bride instructs the daughters of Jerusalem not to awaken or disturb her love until he pleases, underscoring the sacred timing and respect in love.

outline.heading: The Beloved’s Approach and Call to Arise
outline.description: The beloved is described as coming swiftly and joyfully, calling the bride to arise and enjoy the beauty of spring, symbolizing renewal and the blossoming of love.

outline.heading: Warning Against the Little Foxes and Affirmation of Mutual Belonging
outline.description: The bride warns against small threats that can harm their relationship and affirms their mutual belonging and ongoing love until the break of day.

application: Cherish and celebrate the beauty of God-ordained love, recognizing it as a gift to be nurtured with delight and respect.
Honor the timing and boundaries in relationships, waiting patiently for God’s appointed moments to deepen intimacy.
Guard your relationships against small sins or distractions that can damage trust and affection.
Respond to the loving invitation of Christ, who calls His bride to arise and walk in newness of life.

keyVerses.text: He brought me to the banqueting house, and his banner over me was love.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the protective and celebratory nature of love, symbolizing the security found in the beloved’s care.

keyVerses.text: I charge you, O ye daughters of Jerusalem, by the roes, and by the hinds of the field, that ye stir not up, nor awake my love, till he please.
keyVerses.significance: This verse teaches the importance of respecting God’s timing in relationships and not forcing love prematurely.

keyVerses.text: My beloved is mine, and I am his: he feedeth among the lilies.
keyVerses.significance: This verse affirms the mutual belonging and intimate union between the bride and her beloved, reflecting the covenantal nature of love.
